SENT.plain: A 60-year-old man after 5 years of recurrent episodic amaurosis fugax, always resolving, experienced an incident of visual loss that was permanent
Computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging were normal
Transesophageal echocardiogram and carotid duplex scan ruled out embolic sources from the heart and neck vessels
Blood tests for hypercoagulability found elevated APTT not correcting with 50:50 dilution with control serum, owing to the presence of a lupus anticoagulant
The patient was treated with warfarin, baby aspirin, and a calcium channel blocker and has not had a recurrence of permanent visual loss in 17 years
